Award.AwardTitle: RIPS: Type I: A Meta-Network System Framework for Resilient Analysis and Design of Interdependent Critical Infrastructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interdependencies between critical infrastructure systems and processes exacerbate the consequences of initial failure, lead to cascading effects, and compound the propagation of damage. The project enhances the fundamental understanding of interdependent critical infrastructures (ICIs) by providing theoretical guidelines. The framework developed in the project serves as the basis of future computing for a multi-infrastructure modeling, design and simulation platform. This framework interfaces existing software tools for individual infrastructures and enables engineering design and public policy analysis. In addition, the quantitative methodologies developed in this project bridge the disciplines of engineering, computer science, social and economic sciences, and create a new interdisciplinary paradigm that provides a holistic view towards ICI resilience planning and design.

The main focus of this project is to develop a meta-network system framework that captures the physical, cyber and human dependencies within an individual infrastructure and across multiple ICIs and to assess their effects on the outcomes of disastrous events. This theoretical framework considers feedback loops, cascading chains of failures and self-aggravating effects. The identification of network structures or motifs provides insights on the design of resilient ICIs and allows for the quantification of metrics relevant to resilience. The techniques for finding multi-resolution representations of meta-network models provide a system modeling platform that is appropriate not only for designing engineering resilient solutions but also for examining socio-economic policies and communication protocols in the context of organizational behaviors. An event-driven and network-based reliability model provides quantitative metrics such as hitting time and mean time to failure. Control and game theory capture risks and uncertainty and assist in the design of risk-sensitive and robust resilient planning schemes for ICIs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern critical infrastructures are large-scale systems composed of deeply interconnected cyber-physical social systems that are vulnerable to extreme events, such as natural disasters, cyber attacks and terrorism. Interdependencies between and among infrastructure systems can greatly exacerbate the consequence of the initial failure of any single infrastructure, through cascading effects, escalation and compound damage propagation. These often have devastating impacts on society, since they are usually unanticipated with highly uncertain effects. As the protection and prevention approach for critical infrastructures can be expensive and impractical for such events, a paradigm shift in infrastructure security for preparedness and response is critical.

The concept of resilience has been defined in a number of different ways. Resilient infrastructures can be considered as being those that can prepare for and respond to disruptive events and rapidly recover system performance in a desirable time period, and/or with an acceptable cost, and be resistant to future disruptions. This project has provided a systematic framework for designing resilience planning mechanisms to improve the resiliency of interdependent critical infrastructures (ICIs). We have shown that the ICI interdependencies can be captured by networks that represent physical, cyber and human interconnections within an individual infrastructure and across multiple ICIs. The intellectual merit of the research is in providing a new way to formulate networks that captures the nature of interdependencies in a way that ultimately has the flexibility to be applied to multiple situations. Dynamic resilience planning has shown to reduce the cost of the impacts created by disasters and maintain the functions of necessary components in the infrastructure. It also uses cases as a basis to create network formulations. 

Our case studies on Hurricane Sandy in NYC and others have provided insights on the key decision process needed for fast recovery of the infrastructure from disasters. The lessons learned from our case studies can inform and provide decision support for other natural disastrous events such as Irma, Maria and Harvey hurricanes and others yet to come.  The broader impacts of the research include providing outputs in the form of the way in which interdependencies are manifested thus giving insights into how these effects can be managed and reduced by anticipating them.  The broader impacts also include dissemination of the outputs to a very wide range of audiences, including natural sciences, engineering, and social sciences, and members of numerous audiences such as academia, government, and public and private sector infrastructure managers and planners. To accomplish this, the research has been disseminated at conferences and other venues and has been used to educate students in research and classroom teaching environments.
